intro: Rosa canina f. eutransitoria, commonly known as the common dog rose, is a subspecies of the dog rose native to Europe and parts of western Asia. It is a deciduous shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters, featuring thorny stems and compound leaves with five to seven leaflets. The plant produces fragrant, pink to red flowers in spring, which are followed by orange to red hips, its characteristic fruit. Rosa canina f. eutransitoria is valued for its ornamental appeal and has historical uses in herbal medicine. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often found in hedgerows and woodland edges.
